review.title: A Hybrid Citation Retrieval Algorithm for Evidence-based Clinical Knowledge Summarization: Combining Concept Extraction, Vector Similarity and Query Expansion for High Precision
review.abstract: Novel information retrieval methods to identify citations relevant to a clinical topic can overcome the knowledge gap existing between the primary literature (MEDLINE) and online clinical knowledge resources such as UpToDate. Searching the MEDLINE database directly or with query expansion methods returns a large number of citations that are not relevant to the query. The current study presents a citation retrieval system that retrieves citations for evidence-based clinical knowledge summarization. This approach combines query expansion, concept-based screening algorithm, and concept-based vector similarity. We also propose an information extraction framework for automated concept (Population, Intervention, Comparison, and Disease) extraction. We evaluated our proposed system on all topics (as queries) available from UpToDate for two diseases, heart failure (HF) and atrial fibrillation (AFib). The system achieved an overall F-score of 41.2% on HF topics and 42.4% on AFib topics on a gold standard of citations available in UpToDate. This is significantly high when compared to a query-expansion based baseline (F-score of 1.3% on HF and 2.2% on AFib) and a system that uses query expansion with disease hyponyms and journal names, concept-based screening, and term-based vector similarity system (F-score of 37.5% on HF and 39.5% on AFib). Evaluating the system with top K relevant citations, where K is the number of citations in the gold standard achieved a much higher overall F-score of 69.9% on HF topics and 75.1% on AFib topics. In addition, the system retrieved up to 18 new relevant citations per topic when tested on ten HF and six AFib clinical topics.

sections.heading: PICO Framework
sections.text: Formulating a well-focused query is the most important step in the EBM. Identifying relevant citations with a corresponding clinical trial is a major challenge without a well-focused query. Clinicians use a specialized framework called PICO to examine sections of a clinical query that are more suitable for their patients.10,12,23 PICO stands for patient / population - intervention - comparison - result. The PICO framework is expanded to PICOTT (patient / population - intervention - comparison - result - type of question asked - type of study design), 11 PECODR (patient / population / problem - exposure / intervention - comparison - result) 24 and PIBOSO (population - intervention - background - result - study design - others). 25 NLM provides a web-based application for PICO with spelling checks to structure the clinical query. 26 Schardt et.11 used the NLICM comparison to improve the clinical approach.

sections.heading: CONCLUSIONS
sections.text: The citations system we have presented for evidence-based clinical summaries integrates a pipeline of NLP techniques for query extension, concept-based screening, and relevance measurement with concept-based vector similarity. We demonstrated that the accuracy of the citations query is significantly improved by using concept-based vector similarity after population, intervention, or comparison extraction and disease concepts. In addition, the evaluation of the system using Top-K citations showed an overall F score of 69.9% for heart failure and 75.1% for atrial fibrillation, showing the importance of assessing the number of citations to be used by users. Overall, the hybrid combination of concept-based screening algorithm for citations screening and for 51 relevance measurements using concept-based vector similarity shows that few of these citations actually have new findings that are not available online.
